Chapter on Mindfulness of the Body, Part 4
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally the body, following the body.
What kinds of winds are there that dwell in the body, whether in balance or not, and what kind of activities do they perform?
With heard wisdom or the divine eye, he sees a wind called 'destroyer of taste' that dwells in the body. If it is not in balance, what does it do?
With heard wisdom or the divine eye, he sees:

If the 'destroyer of taste' wind is not in balance, it causes the sweet-loving worms in the tongue to move. Because of the worms moving, one cannot eat any delicious food, and because of not eating, the body becomes weak and unable to study, cultivate meditation, or practice good dharmas. Because the body is not in balance, the mind does not delight in the Dharma. Name and form abide in mutual causality, just like bundles of bamboo that stand together.

Due to the power of mutual dependence, name-and-form mutually rely on each other. In this way, the aggregate of formations abides due to the condition of food, like water and flour are called flour gruel, each having power, and name-and-form can abide.
If the wind is in harmony, then there will be no illness as described above.
Having contemplated the wind that destroys taste, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally within the body,
What winds are there in the body, whether in harmony or not, and what work do they do?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see a wind called lung-passing, which is in the body. If in harmony or not, what does it do?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see:

If the lung-passing wind is not in harmony, when the desire for food is digested, it causes pain at night, makes the food sour, and even when the food is digested, the whole body becomes weak, and the veins are bound like a net.
If the wind is in harmony, then there will be none of the above-mentioned illnesses.
Having contemplated the lung wind, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally the body, observing the body.
What kinds of winds are present in the body, and what activities do they perform when in harmony or disharmony?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see a wind called 'ascending stench,' and what does it do when in harmony or disharmony?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see:

The ascending stench wind makes the body, nose, and mouth all stinky, and can cause foul odors to come out from the pores. It rushes up from the mature intestines to the raw intestines, making the whole body very painful and difficult, food is undigested, one cannot sit in meditation, and day and night one cannot practice good dharmas.
If the ascending stench wind is harmonious and in balance, then there will be none of the above-mentioned illnesses.
Having contemplated the ascending wind, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally the body according to the body.
What kinds of winds are there that dwell in the body, whether in balance or imbalanced, and what kind of activities do they perform?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see a wind called the rectum, which, whether in balance or imbalanced, does what?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see:

If the rectal wind is not in harmony, it will cause hemorrhoids in the three flesh pouches, with blood discharged like red bean juice, a burning sensation in the body, drowsiness, constricted sinews and veins, inability to digest food, and an inability to taste with the tongue.
If the wind is in balance, then there will be no such illness.
Having contemplated the rectal wind, he understands the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally the body according to the body.
What kinds of winds are there that dwell in the body, whether in balance or imbalanced, and what kind of activities do they perform?
Using his heard-acquired wisdom or the divine eye, he sees a wind called forgetfulness located in the body. If it is disturbed, what does it do?
Using his heard-acquired wisdom or the divine eye, he sees:

If the forgetfulness wind is disturbed, it causes forgetfulness. One often forgets what one has learned and cannot remember it. One's views in the four directions are upside down. One forgets and cannot remember past events. One quickly becomes hungry after eating and cannot eat. The body hair is rough and the nails are the same. One cannot endure cold or heat. One forgets what one thinks of.
If the wind is in balance, one will not have the above-mentioned illnesses.
Having contemplated the forgetfulness wind, he knows the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the body in the body.
What winds are located in the body, and what do they do if they are disturbed or in balance?
Using their heard-understanding or the divine eye, they see a wind called generating strength residing in the body. If it is unbalanced, what does it do?
Using their heard-understanding or the divine eye, they see:
If the generating strength wind is unbalanced, even if one eats many delicious foods, the body will always be weak, as if poisoned.
This illness is caused by the wind being unbalanced. If the wind is balanced, then there will be no such illness.
Having contemplated the generating strength wind, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, following the body in contemplation.
What kinds of winds reside in the body, either balanced or unbalanced, and what kind of activities do they perform?
Using their heard-understanding or the divine eye, they see a wind called generating physical and mental strength residing in the body. If it is unbalanced, what does it do?
Using their heard-understanding or the divine eye, they see the generating physical and mental strength wind:
If the wind is in harmony, it gradually increases the body and mind from the womb, making the mind strong and healthy.

Because the wind is in harmony, one knows what to do and what not to do. One can remember what was done a long time ago. One's comings and goings, advances and retreats, are strong and healthy, unafraid of hunger, thirst, cold, heat, and various sufferings. The body is full, and the hair on the body does not turn white prematurely.
If it is not in harmony, one loses these qualities.
Having observed the wind that generates physical strength and mind, one understands the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, following the body in contemplation.
What kinds of winds are there in the body, whether in harmony or not, and what kind of activities do they perform?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see a wind called 'obstructing the throat and speech' that resides in the body. If it is not in harmony, what does it do?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see:

If the wind that obstructs the throat and speech is not in harmony, it gives rise to physical illness. If the other [winds] are not in harmony, then one loses one's voice, or sometimes becomes deaf, or one's hands and feet become paralyzed, or one's body becomes bent over and hunchbacked, or one's two eyes become blind.
Because the wind is not in harmony, such illnesses arise.
Having contemplated the wind that obstructs the throat and speech, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally the body according to the body.
What kinds of winds are there that dwell in the body, and what activities do they perform when in harmony or not in harmony?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see a wind called the sleep wind. If it is not in harmony, what does it do?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see:
If the sleep wind is not in harmony, one's perceptions are inverted, and it disturbs the flowing vessels, causing them to move and change, and all the joints ache.
Having contemplated the sleep wind, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally the body according to the body.
What kinds of winds are there that reside in the body, whether in balance or imbalanced, and what kind of activities do they perform?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see a wind called life-sustaining that resides in the body. If it is in balance or imbalanced, what does it do?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see:
If the life-sustaining wind is not in harmony, it causes people to lose their lives and abandon their awareness.

It is the second life of all beings, able to sustain the body, relying on the conscious mind. Due to imbalance, it can end a person's life. It relies on and sustains the life faculty of all beings. If the wind is in balance, it does not cause an untimely death.
Having contemplated the life-sustaining wind, one accurately understands the body.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally the body according to the body.
What kinds of winds are there that reside in the body, whether in balance or imbalanced, and what kind of activities do they perform?
Using their heard-based wisdom or the divine eye, they see a wind called destroyer of all body parts residing in the body. If it is out of balance, what does it do?
Using their heard-based wisdom or the divine eye, they see:

The destroyer of the body wind begins from when one resides in the womb. The power of this wind causes the body parts to break down and be damaged, the body becomes bent and hunchbacked, with a protruding chest and crooked hips.
If the wind is in balance, then there will be no such illness.
Having contemplated the destroyer of the body wind, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, following the body in contemplation.
What winds reside in the body and what activities do they perform?
Using their heard-based wisdom or the divine eye, they contemplate and see a wind called skin-gathering residing in the body. What does it do?
Using their heard-based wisdom or the divine eye, they see:

If the skin-collecting wind is touched by external wind, whether cold or hot, fragrant or foul-smelling, moving downward or upward, with great or little force, it can sense and know it all according to the time it comes in contact.
Having contemplated the skin-collecting wind, one understands the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, following the body in contemplation.
What winds abide in the body?

With heard wisdom or the divine eye, free from turbidity, with pure objects, free from doubt, having crossed over doubt, having crossed over the wilderness, not doubting as it truly is, there is no other wind in this body.
This wind gathers, this wind combines, this wind flows, relying on the faculties and elements, abiding together with karma and afflictions, able to sustain the body, or causing harm.

The practitioner observes all the winds in the body in detail, and having seen them completely, he becomes disgusted and detached, and desire cannot destroy him. He does not enter the realm of MÄra, but approaches nirvÄá¹‡a. With the sun of wisdom, he breaks the darkness of greed, hatred, and delusion that has been turning since beginningless time. He leaves behind the wilderness of doubt and does not become attached to form, sound, smell, taste, or touch. He sees things as they really are in the realms, and sees that everything in the three realms is impermanent, suffering, empty, and without self, as it really is.

Thus, the bhiká¹£us who practice in the villages of the brÄhmaá¹‡as and householders of NaradÄ«pa truly understand this pleasant cultivation of mindfulness of the body, know the Dharma of arising and ceasing, do not think of other contemplations, observe the entire body, and know all bonds and liberation.
Furthermore, the practitioner observes this body's loss, destruction, and cessation with a different method.
How will this body be lost?
When life ends, how do wind and worms destroy this body?
How is it disturbed?
How long does one live in each realm before dying?
How are the winds that blow above and below, in reverse and in sequence?
In this way, the bhiká¹£u contemplates the internal body, and with his wisdom from hearing [the Dharma] or with the divine eye, he sees:
When one is about to die, all the worms are first disturbed, and when the worms die, the person's life ends. All conditioned [phenomena] are certain to be lost and destroyed.
Such a law of death must have this great and firm evil.
In this way, the bhiká¹£u contemplates the head and sees that there are ten kinds of worms that are killed by the wind:
The first is called the top-of-the-head worm, which is killed by the toenail wind;
The second is called the brain worm, which is killed by the wind on the sides of the two feet;
The third is called the skull worm, which is killed by the wind of unawareness;ğŸ”½The fourth is called the hair-eating worm, which is killed by the wind that breaks the bones;
The fifth is called the ear-moving worm, which is killed by the wind that moves and treads on the ground;
Sixth, the flowing tears worm is killed by the wind that destroys the ankles;
Seventh, the fat-moving worm is killed by the wind that destroys the shins;
Eighth, the interlocking teeth and joints worm;ğŸ”½Ninth, the saliva-eating worm is killed by the wind that destroys the joints of the feet and ankles;
Tenth, the tooth-root-eating worm is killed by the wind that destroys the thigh bones.
Furthermore, there are ten kinds of worms that move in the throat and down to the chest, killed by the wind.
What are the ten?
First, the food-eating worm and second, the saliva-eating worm are killed by the power-destroying wind;

Third, the spittle worm, fourth, the vomiting worm, fifth, the worm that moves in the ten flavor channels is killed by the moving and turning wind;ğŸ”½Sixth, the sweet-intoxicated worm is killed by the joint-harming wind;
Seventh, the worm that enjoys the six flavors is killed by the wind that destroys hair, nails, and feces;
Eighth, the 'air-pumping worm' is killed by the 'correct jumping wind';ğŸ”½Ninth, the 'taste-hating worm' is killed by the 'destructive wind';
Tenth, the 'sleep-loving worm' is killed by the 'uterine wind' twenty.
Furthermore, there are ten kinds of worms that live in the blood and are killed by the wind:
First, the 'hair-eating worm' is killed by the 'dry feces wind';
Second, the 'hole-crawling worm' is killed by the 'two sides wind';
Third, the 'chan-du worm' is killed by the 'six orifices wind';
Fourth, the 'red worm' is killed by the 'body-part-cutting wind';
Fifth, the 'mother-of-roundworms' is killed by the 'evil-fire wind';
Sixth, the 'hair-lamp worm' is killed by the 'all-body-part wind';
Seventh, the 'hair-eating worm' and 'blood-hating worm' are killed by the 'breaking-bone wind';
Ninth, the slimy worms are killed by the wind that moves all the body.
Tenth, the sour worms are killed by the hot wind.

Born in the blood, their form is short and round, without feet, tiny and eyeless, able to cause bodily itching, moving weakly. Those worms taste salty. At the time of a person's death, after being killed by the wind, the blood then dries up, and the person dies. Therefore, people say that a dead person has no blood.
Because the blood is about to dry up, one obtains great suffering.

When one is about to die, the mind is greatly frightened, and one experiences great suffering. Fearing to abandon this body and go to another place, one is separated from relatives, acquaintances, brothers, wives, children, and wealth. Ignorant and attached to love, bound by the bonds of love, without protection, without the companionship of good dharmas, alone, with all the body's blood vessels dried up, one experiences the great suffering of both body and mind.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally the body following the body.
What kind of worms are killed by the wind, and what kind of suffering do they experience?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see ten kinds of worms living in the flesh.
What are the ten?
The first is called the wound-producing worm, which is killed by the moving wind;
the second is called the thorn worm, which is killed by the ascending and descending winds;
the third is called the tendon-closing worm, which is killed by the life-sustaining wind.
Why is it called the life-sustaining wind?
If it leaves the body, a person's life ends, so it is called the life-sustaining wind.
The fourth is called the moving-vein worm, which is killed by the opening wind;
the fifth is called the skin worm, which is killed by the chaotic-mind wind;ğŸ”½the sixth is called the moving-fat worm, which is killed by the disturbing wind;
the seventh is called the gathering worm, which is killed by the winking wind;
Eighth are the stinking worms, ninth are the filthy worms, and tenth are the hot worms. They are killed by the five closing winds at the time of death.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally the body, following the body.
How does white sweat flow out at the time of death?
In this way, the worms move in the yin [channels]. By which wind are they killed?
The practitioner contemplates ten kinds of worms moving in the bile.
What are the ten?
First are the worms called sliminess, killed by the wind that destroys the womb;
whether male or female, at the time of death, this wind severs the vessels.
Second are the worms called exhaustion, killed by the wind that turns the womb;
whether male or female, it causes loss of strength, or a cup of yellow like gold is emitted from the mouth.
Third are the worms called sprout flowers, killed by the wind that comes and goes, moves and stops;

Fourth, the great deceit worm; fifth, the worm that moves through holes; sixth, the black worm; seventh, the great eating worm; eighth, the hot-moving worm, which is killed by the wind that destroys the eyes, ears, nose, tongue, and body.
In this way, in order, ninth is the great heat worm, which is killed by the knife wind;
tenth is the taste-eating worm, which is killed by the needle-pricking wind;
eleventh is the fire worm, which is killed by the evil yellow wind;
twelfth is the great fire worm, which is killed by the wind that breaks the intestines.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally the body, following the body.
He contemplates the bone worms, when at the end of life, by what wind are they killed?
He sees with his hearing wisdom or with the divine eye that inside the bones of all parts of the body there are ten kinds of worms.
What are the ten?
First, the bone-licking worm is killed by the wind that causes yellowing;
Second, the gnawing bone worm is killed by the cold wind;
Third, the joint-breaking worm is killed by the marrow-injuring wind;
Fourth, the red-mouthed stinking worm is killed by the skin-injuring wind;
Fifth, the bone-dissolving worm is killed by the blood-injuring wind;
Sixth, the red-mouthed worm is killed by the flesh-injuring wind;
Seventh, the tou tou mo worm and eighth, the skin-eating worm are killed by the bone-injuring wind;ğŸ”½Ninth, the wind-knife worm is killed by the essence-injuring wind;
Tenth, the knife-mouthed worm is killed by the wrinkled-skin wind.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally the body, observing the body.
He observes the worms in feces, when at the time of death, by what kind of wind are they killed?
He sees with his hearing wisdom or with the divine eye ten kinds of worms.
What are the ten?
The first is called the born worm, which is killed by the wind of the power of birth;ğŸ”½The second is called the needle-mouth worm, which is killed by the wind that injures sweat;
The third is called the white-joint worm, which is killed by the wind of numbness;
The fourth is called the legless worm, which is killed by the wind that injures sweat;
The fifth is called the scattered feces worm, which is killed by the wind that breaks teeth;
The sixth is called the three-burned worm, which is killed by the wind of the throat veins;
The seventh is called the broken-injured worm, which is killed by the wind that moves downward;
The eighth is called the closed-food-digesting worm, which is killed by the wind that moves upward;
The ninth is called the yellow worm, which is killed by the two side winds;
The tenth is called the heavy-food-digesting worm, which is killed by the wind that supports the sinews.

This wind and worms cause the feces to dry up, disturb the elements, move and activate each other, and collide with each other. The wind all moves upward, disturbs the body elements, destroys the breath, agitates the body, causes it to dry up, and kills it with force.
When a person is dying, they experience great suffering and distress, which cannot be compared to anything. All worldly people will die, without a doubt.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally the body, observing the body.
He observes the worms in the marrow, when at the time of death, by what wind are they killed?
He sees with his hearing-wisdom or with the divine eye that there are ten kinds of worms in the marrow.
What are the ten?
1. The first is called the hair worm, which is killed by the marrow-harming wind;
2. The second is called the black-mouthed worm, which is killed by the wind resembling a little;
3. The third is called the powerless worm, which is killed by the wind that disturbs sleep and vision;
Fourth, the pain-disturbing worm is killed by the wind of intolerance;
Fifth, the heart-stifling worm is killed by the wind of names and forms;
Sixth, the fire-colored worm is killed by the tight wind;
Seventh, the slippery worm is killed by the wind in the lungs;
Eighth, the downward-flowing worm is killed by the stinking upward-moving wind;
Ninth, the body-root-producing worm is killed by the wind moving in the anus;
Tenth, the memory-joyful worm is killed by the forgetfulness wind eighty.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, having seen impermanence, impurity, and no-self.
Previously, one worm was killed by the wind injuring the lungs. Such worms, when approaching death, are killed by the wind.

In this way, the bhiká¹£u contemplates the internal body, using the pure and bright [mind] to eliminate the darkness of beginningless cyclic existence, forever extinguished. Using worldly similar karma, he attains this Dharma. Because of cultivating the seven kinds of mindfulness for a long time, he sees them directly. What are the seven?
First, mindfulness of the Buddha;
Second, mindfulness of the Dharma;
Third, mindfulness of the Saá¹…gha;
Fourth, mindfulness of precepts;
Fifth, mindfulness of heaven;
Sixth, mindfulness of death;
Seventh, mindfulness of impermanence.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body.
Contemplating death, how many kinds destroy all karma?
He observes with his wisdom from hearing or with the divine eye that there are four kinds of death:
Namely, the earth element is not in balance, the water element is not in balance, the fire element is not in balance, and the wind element is not in balance.
How does the imbalance of the earth element end a person's life?

If the earth element is not in balance, the bodily wind energy causes the earth element to become solid, causing the entire body to become constricted, mutually destroying and oppressing each other. It is like two mountains as hard as vajra, between which is placed a lump of fresh butter, and a great black wind blows, causing the two mountains to collide and crush the lump of fresh butter.

The earth element and wind element are like those two mountains. All the life in the body, the skin, flesh, bones, blood, fat, marrow, and vital energy, are contained in the body like a box, just like fresh butter, being struck and oppressed by the earth element and wind element, destroying the body's elements, experiencing great suffering, unable to contemplate the Buddha, Dharma, and Saá¹ƒgha, the present aggregates are about to end, bound by the intermediate existence, continuing without interruption.

All foolish ordinary people, with minds similar and continuously arising through conditions, are like what is stamped by a seal. Death is also like this. When the present aggregates are about to end, the similar mind arises and is also similar. Because of the power of the conditions of the mind-monkey, one experiences birth and death.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally the body following the body.
He contemplates when life ends, how does the water element become unbalanced, causing me and all foolish ordinary people to lose our lives?
He sees with his heard wisdom or with the divine eye that when the water element becomes unbalanced,

the muscles and veins of the entire body, all the skin, flesh, bones, blood, fat, marrow, and vital energy of me and sentient beings at the time of death, all rot, pus and blood flow out, they oppress each other, all move, like two mountains pressing down, also as previously explained, like a lump of fresh butter placed in the ocean, blown by a black wind, the huge waves clashing, unstoppable, without solidity or firmness.
In the same way, when the water element destroys the body, one is unable to think of the Buddha, Dharma, and Saá¹ƒgha jewels, but other thoughts continue without interruption.

All foolish ordinary beings receive bodies similar to their minds, like what is stamped by a seal. At the time of death, when the current aggregates are exhausted, they receive similar rebirths. In the same way, the mind-monkey undergoes birth and death, leading one into birth and death.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, following the body in contemplation.
How does the fire element, when out of balance, end a person's life?
He sees with his heard-based wisdom or with the divine eye:

At the time of death, when the fire element is out of balance, all the body's channels, all the sinews, all the tendons, skin, flesh, bones, blood, fat, marrow, and essence are all burned, cooked, and fiercely ablaze.
It is like burning khadira charcoal, with a mountain-like mass of fire, throwing in fresh butter, burning it with flames rising, in the same way, the body is like a lump of butter thrown into it.
The suffering of death is also like this, unable to think of the Three Jewels of the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha.
When the present aggregates are about to end, the mind continues to think. All foolish ordinary beings, with the mind as the condition, receive birth in a similar way, like what is stamped by a seal.

At the time of death, when the present aggregates are exhausted and the mind receives birth, it is also like this. Due to the power of the conditions of the mind-monkey, one experiences birth and death.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the body internally, in accordance with reality.
How does the wind element become unbalanced at the time of death and sever a person's life?
He sees with his heard-based wisdom or the divine eye:

At the time of death, when the wind element is unbalanced, all parts of the body, all the sinews and blood vessels, and all the bodily elements, namely skin, flesh, bones, blood, fat, marrow, and vital essence, all disperse and decay, becoming dry and greasy, cutting and tearing each other, scattering like sand from head to toe.

It is like a lump of butter blown by a black wind, scattering and losing its grease, dispersing like sand in the sky. When a person's life ends and the wind element is unbalanced, oppressed by the suffering of death, it is also like this, unable to think of the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha treasures again.
All ordinary people have conditioned minds that continue to arise, like what is stamped by a seal. At the time of death, an exhausted mind arises, and it is also like this.
By the power of the causes and conditions of the monkey-like mind, one receives a body subject to birth, old age, sickness, and death.
This is called the four great elements being unbalanced, resulting in four kinds of death. The practitioner, having seen this, observes impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and no-self.

Having seen this, they do not approach the realm of MÄra, but approach the path to nirvÄá¹‡a. They do not delight in or become attached to defiled forms, sounds, smells, tastes, and tactile objects, do not give rise to a mind of craving, are free from the defilements of dust, are free from the wilderness, are not attached to forms, sounds, smells, tastes, and tactile objects, do not give rise to conceit about forms, do not rely on youthfulness, do not rely on conceit about life, do not delight in much speech, do not enter cities, are not biased towards anything, always think of the fear of death, are afraid of even the slightest wrongdoing, know the body as it truly is, know the dharma of arising and ceasing, and in all defiled desires, their minds are disgusted and they delight in practicing the true Dharma without laziness.
Thus, the bhiká¹£us who practice in the villages of brahmins and householders observe and practice.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally, following the body in observation.
How do they contemplate the internal and external body? It means that after contemplating external phenomena, they contemplate the internal body, following the body in observation.

Observing the seeds, like seeds producing sprouts, from sprouts producing stems, from stems producing leaves, from leaves producing flowers, and from flowers producing fruits, is called external observation.

Furthermore, the practitioner observes the internal body, the previous consciousness seeds together with karmic afflictions entering impurity, called anÄbhoga, from anÄbhoga, called kalala, from kalala, called ghana, from ghana, called flesh lump, from the flesh lump, the five limbs are produced, namely two hands, two feet, and head, from the five limbs, the five sense organs are produced, in this way, in sequence, up to old age and death.
Furthermore, the practitioner externally observes the body in accordance with its development.
How is it that grass and trees are first seen green, then gradually turn yellow, and finally fall?
The body is also like this, first seen as an infant, then reaching middle age, gradually reaching old age, and finally returning to death.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates in accordance with the external body.
How do external seeds grow?
From the earth, all medicinal herbs and groves grow and flourish.
He sees with his wisdom of hearing or with the divine eye:

These dharmas each have their own causes and conditions, and each has its own power, whether internal or external, all conditioned things, except for three kinds of dharmas, namely, conditioned space, unconditioned space, and the space of nirvana.
How do dharmas each transform with their own power?

Namely, ignorance conditions formations, formations condition consciousness, consciousness conditions name-and-form, name-and-form conditions the six sense bases, the six sense bases condition contact, contact conditions feeling, feeling conditions craving, craving conditions grasping, grasping conditions becoming, becoming conditions birth, birth conditions old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress. Thus arises the whole great mass of suffering.

If ignorance ceases, then karmic formations cease. If karmic formations cease, then consciousness ceases. If consciousness ceases, then name-and-form cease. If name-and-form cease, then the six sense bases cease. If the six sense bases cease, then contact ceases. If contact ceases, then feeling ceases. If feeling ceases, then craving ceases. If craving ceases, then grasping ceases. If grasping ceases, then existence ceases. If existence ceases, then birth ceases. If birth ceases, then old age, death, grief, lamentation, suffering, distress, and mental anguish cease. Thus, the mass of great suffering ceases.
Thus, these phenomena, whether internal or external, arise and grow in mutual dependence.

Thus, the practitioner contemplates internally and externally, in accordance with the three kinds of external body elements, contemplating internally as externally and externally as internally, observing in accordance with reality.

In this way, the practitioner observes internal and external phenomena. First, observing JambudvÄ«pa, in order to increase the correct Dharma, cultivating internal Dharma observation, discriminating and contemplating, each contemplation, human and heavenly combined observation, separate contemplation without thought, internal causes in external, all four elements, external causes in internal, mind and mental factors, there is internal Dharma, external Dharma increase.
If there is internal Dharma, correctly understanding internal Dharma, if internal Dharma increases, seeing external is understood.
How do internal dharmas increase due to external causes?
Beds, bedding, and necessary medical supplies are all complete, and the bhiká¹£us are then able to increase good dharmas;
If there are no bedding, medical supplies, and so forth, they are unable to increase all good dharmas, and have no desire to seek them.
In this way, internal and external mutually rely on each other to increase, not created by a doer, not permanent and unchanging, not born without a cause.
